Recommended Reason: 11th-13th century capital of Zimbabwe kingdom with documented gold processing, soapstone Zimbabwe Birds, and extensive archaeological evidence of wealth
Supporting Evidence: Eight carved soapstone Zimbabwe Birds found, gold processing crucibles discovered, UNESCO World Heritage site with documented treasure finds

Recommended Reason: 13th-15th century main residential area with evidence of gold and copper working, trade with Indian Ocean, Chinese ceramics and Syrian glass found
Supporting Evidence: Archaeological excavations revealed Chinese celadon dishes, Persian faience bowls, Syrian glass, gold foil and processing equipment

Recommended Reason: 14th-16th century settlement area with evidence of gold refining, over 100 gold processing vessels found in recent excavations
Supporting Evidence: New excavations yielded fragments of over 100 gold processing vessels, reused pottery and purpose-made crucibles for gold collection

Recommended Reason: 15th-17th century capital after Great Zimbabwe's decline, sophisticated stonework and pottery techniques transferred from Great Zimbabwe
Supporting Evidence: UNESCO World Heritage site, evidence of continued gold working traditions, sophisticated stone architecture indicating wealth

Recommended Reason: Major stone-walled site with evidence of extensive copper working and trade, individuals buried with large amounts of copper and gold
Supporting Evidence: Archaeological evidence shows individuals buried with huge amounts of gold and copper, part of Great Zimbabwe cultural complex

Recommended Reason: 17th century stone-walled settlement with evidence of gold trade and sophisticated architecture, part of regional Zimbabwe culture
Supporting Evidence: Stone architecture indicates wealth and trade connections, part of network of sites connected to Great Zimbabwe traditions

Location: Chisikana Spring Sacred Site, Great Zimbabwe
Recommended Reason: Sacred spring considered holy by local communities, associated with foundation myths and potentially ritual deposits of valuables
Supporting Evidence: Archaeological research identifies spring as control point for visitors, sacred status suggests potential for ritual offerings

Recommended Reason: Linear-intrusive quartz vein used as control point for access to Great Zimbabwe, potential for tribute and toll collections
Supporting Evidence: 7.8 meter long quartz ridge used by locals as control point for visitors entering and exiting Great Zimbabwe

Location: Zimbabwe Birds Eastern Enclosure Site, Great Zimbabwe
Recommended Reason: Six of eight famous Zimbabwe Birds found here, royal authority symbols with potential for additional undiscovered soapstone treasures
Supporting Evidence: Six Zimbabwe Birds recovered from Eastern Enclosure, these serve as status and religious symbols emblematic of royal authority

Location: Early Colonial Treasure Hunter Sites, Great Zimbabwe
Recommended Reason: Areas looted by antiquarians 1890s-1920s left behind items, potential for scattered artifacts and incomplete recoveries
Supporting Evidence: Historical accounts confirm large amounts of gold fell into hands of antiquarians, much archaeological evidence destroyed but items may remain
